VIII.iv.1.E.1.a
.
General Information on Personal Trauma
Personal trauma
, for the purpose of Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) disability compensation claims, refers broadly to stressor events (also referred to as “personal traumatic events”) involving harm perpetrated by a person who is not considered part of an enemy force.
Examples
:  Assault, battery, robbery, mugging, stalking, harassment.
Military sexual trauma
(MST) is a subset of personal trauma and refers to sexual harassment, sexual assault, or rape that occurs during military service.
Notes
:
MST and other types of personal trauma are events that may result in disability, but they are not disabilities in and of themselves.
Experiences of MST are not limited to a specific sex or background.
The perpetrator of an MST or other personal traumatic event may or may not be affiliated with the military.
Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is commonly associated with MST and other types of personal trauma, and service connection (SC) for PTSD on this basis may be established under the provisions of
38 CFR 3.304(f)(5)
.  However, PTSD is not the only diagnosis that can result from personal traumatic events.
References
:  For more information on
the definition of MST, see
38 U.S.C. 1166(d)(2)
handling claims based on MST without an associated claimed disability, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.B.1.e
, and
M21-1, Part II, Subpart iii, 1.C.2.d
processing claims for PTSD based on personal trauma, see
the
PTSD Personal Assault Information
site on the Compensation Service Intranet, and
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.B
, and
handling claims for SC for non-PTSD conditions based on an in-service personal traumatic event, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.B.1.b and c
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.B.2.a
, and
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.D.2.k
.
